replies.htmlContent: This one seems nearly impossible to quantify in a meaningful way. Do we have to do this? As I mentioned I worry about overwhelming with data. This might be an example where we are trying too hard to shove some data at the team.
replies.content: This one seems nearly impossible to quantify in a meaningful way. Do we have to do this? As I mentioned I worry about overwhelming with data. This might be an example where we are trying too hard to shove some data at the team.

replies.htmlContent: Maybe for this entire section, we can show "Total actions" as defined in the tool or selected through interaction by the team and "Total revisions". However, revisions is a subset of the total actions data so maybe its something that is selectable.
replies.content: Maybe for this entire section, we can show "Total actions" as defined in the tool or selected through interaction by the team and "Total revisions". However, revisions is a subset of the total actions data so maybe its something that is selectable.

replies.htmlContent:
Having the team contract is helpful in setting up an abstract goal/standard but we still lack a benchmark here; ideas we have so far include:
1) compare with class average (min/max)
2) ask the team to set up their own "baseline", e.g. how they would want to divide the work and how they want to set up planning
Both are already in Figma or implemented.

Another idea I have is to simply not have any benchmark but just neutrally present the data, then ask the students to reflect according to the corresponding team contract points

However, this can not show a relatively conclusive result, especially in giving early warning signals to instructors or grading the process. So, maybe some low threshold should still be set?
replies.content:
Having the team contract is helpful in setting up an abstract goal/standard but we still lack a benchmark here; ideas we have so far include:
1) compare with class average (min/max)
2) ask the team to set up their own "baseline", e.g. how they would want to divide the work and how they want to set up planning
Both are already in Figma or implemented.

Another idea I have is to simply not have any benchmark but just neutrally present the data, then ask the students to reflect according to the corresponding team contract points

However, this can not show a relatively conclusive result, especially in giving early warning signals to instructors or grading the process. So, maybe some low threshold should still be set?

comments.content: multiple metrics, e.g. edits, words, commits, codes -> choose one (per tool) as primary with others as alternatives, or find some aggregated metric to define one "action/contribution"
comments.author: Yifan Song

replies.htmlContent: Right - this is why so much prior work uses a single tool because it avoids the problem of aggregation across tools. They still get the work published. Makes me worry we are trying to do too much
replies.content: Right - this is why so much prior work uses a single tool because it avoids the problem of aggregation across tools. They still get the work published. Makes me worry we are trying to do too much

replies.htmlContent: My initial thought is to define Total Actions, and count specific actions per tool. Such as Edits and comments in Docs, Commits in GitHub, substantive posts in Slack. I can imagine this as a simple timeline with different colors or shapes representing types of actions and size indicating volume. Or even a series of charts showing actions by time or group member. I still struggle with showing group members because it pits team members against each other.
replies.content: My initial thought is to define Total Actions, and count specific actions per tool. Such as Edits and comments in Docs, Commits in GitHub, substantive posts in Slack. I can imagine this as a simple timeline with different colors or shapes representing types of actions and size indicating volume. Or even a series of charts showing actions by time or group member. I still struggle with showing group members because it pits team members against each other.

replies.htmlContent: Whether students want to see their teammates' data and/or how they want their data to be presented may be a problem we need to find out through user study - maybe we can present multiple visual representations during the study
replies.content: Whether students want to see their teammates' data and/or how they want their data to be presented may be a problem we need to find out through user study - maybe we can present multiple visual representations during the study

comments.content: is respectful and professional different? Would they be measured in different ways?
comments.author: Brian Bailey

replies.htmlContent: I like having these words, just curious if they are substantially different in our intent as to what they capture.
replies.content: I like having these words, just curious if they are substantially different in our intent as to what they capture.

replies.htmlContent: I think "respectful" is like a lower bound of "professional", maybe we can only keep "professional" in the contract as it should include "respectful"
replies.content: I think "respectful" is like a lower bound of "professional", maybe we can only keep "professional" in the contract as it should include "respectful"

replies.htmlContent: though we can start by visualizing measures of respectfulness, which might be easier, then explore more complex professionalism measures such as ambiguity or helpfulness
replies.content: though we can start by visualizing measures of respectfulness, which might be easier, then explore more complex professionalism measures such as ambiguity or helpfulness

comments.content: I don't think this is a viable choice. Full consensus means "unanimous" and I wonder if this is really a choice a team must make in a contract. I think the more important issue is to discuss important decisions as a team rather than the method of voting
comments.author: Brian Bailey

replies.htmlContent: Maybe this point can be removed and merged into inclusiveness?
replies.content: Maybe this point can be removed and merged into inclusiveness?
